posts.body:
The Caddo Creation Story

The Caddo Nation is a confederacy of multiple Southeastern Native American tribes in the southeast. Their ancestors, the Caddoan Mississippian culture, lived in a large territory that covered parts of what are now Oklahoma, Arkansas, Texas, and Louisiana.

The Caddo creation story, preserve in oral histories and traditional dances, says that people and animals emerged from a cave in what is now Louisiana. The principal leader, Moon, divided the people into groups and led the people out of the cave. He bid the others not to look back.

The first man who emerged carried a pipe and fire in one hand and a drum in the other. The first woman who emerged carried corn and pumpkin seeds.

One of the group leaders, Coyote, became scared and looked backward. The cave closed up, trapping the rest of the people and animals below. Those who had made it above began to weep, and their tears formed a lake, the Chahkanina, the “land of the crying place.”

This story is adapted from a reading by storyteller Kricket Rhoads-Connywerdy. You can find it here.

You can learn about Kricket Rhoads-Connywerdy here.

posts.body:
Pre-contact Native American Cities

There were a number of large population centers in the Americas. I will be focusing on those in what is now the US and Canada, but large cities also existed south of the Rio Grande.

Generally considered the greatest pre-Columbian Native American city, Cahokia once sat directly across the river from what is now St. Louis, Missouri. It was settled around 600 CE and existed from 1050-1350 CE, with its apex around 1100 CE. Cahokia likely had more than 20,000 people living in (thousands more than London, at the time) and was the most influential urban settlement of the Mississippian culture.

Cahokia, on the Mississippi River, was an important center for trade and agriculture. It maintained trade links with communities from the Great Lakes to the Gulf Coast and had people living outside the main urban center. Cahokia, and the Mississippians who built it, were known for their incredible urban planning and the mounds that made up the city center. Today, the Cahokia Mounds are a UNESCO World Heritage site.

Second, the Poverty Point (named after a 19th-century plantation on top of it) culture was centralized in what is now northeastern Louisiana. Like Cahokia, it had a number of important mounds for urban life. It was constructed over multiple generations, and radiocarbon dating suggests that earthwork construction was in progress from 1800-1200 BCE. Poverty Point is one of the most ancient cities in the Americas. Poverty Point had a rich material culture include fired earthware, copperwork, and stone vessels. They had manufacturing and long-distance trade.

Third, the Calusa (Caloosahatchee) people of the southwest coast of Florida, on the coast of the Gulf. They also built mounds and, at the time of European contact in the 16th century, had a population in the 10,000s. They were likely the only indigenous North Americans who established a kingdom without practicing agriculture, using the abundant fishing resources instead. The main mound, Mound Key, was a manmade structure with canals, watercourts, and other features. The Calusa were notable for their carved-wood art and their sophisticated engineering and architecture. A single manor on Mound Key was capable of holding 2,000 people.

Fourth, the Mogollon culture was one of the major cultures of southwest America. It had multiple large and dense settlements, but one that’s considered a proper city. Called Paquimé, it was settled from 1130-1450 CE. It had a population in the thousands, who lived in multi-story buildings and an irrigation-based agricultural economy. They had a complex system of water control that included drainage, reservoirs, channels, and sewage. The city had a market, ballcourts, and the production of copper and ceramic objects.

The final city to discuss is Etzanoa. Located in what is now Arkansas City, Kansas on the Arkansas River, it actually flourished after and alongside European contact, mostly with the Spanish. Etzanoa housed approximately 20,000 people. It was a seat of power for the Wichita and a trading hub.


[Image Description: A black and white map of the United States. States are outlined but not labeled. Five stars mark the location of cities. Cahokia is on the border of Arkansas and Illinois. Etzanoa is on the border of Kansas and Oklahoma. Poverty Point is on the border of Louisiana and Mississippi. Mound Key is in southern Florida. Paquimé is slightly below New Mexico.

posts.body:
Pre-contact Native American Demography

Estimates of the number of Native Americans vary, but all agree that the land was home to, at a minimum, tens of millions of people. In 1492, estimates range for a Native population from 50 million to over 100 million. The indigenous population of the United States ranges from 4 to 18 million, while the indigenous population of Canada was as much as 2 million.

One interesting point–this was likely not the highest Native American population. That was 5,000 years ago, well before Columbus arrived in 1492.

It was after Columbus, however, that numbers began to drop steeply. Historians agree that the actions of settlers, especially disease and violence, killed about 90% of Native Americans (totaling about 10% of the population of the entire world, at that time).

It is important to understand that the diseases traveled much faster than the Europeans, so many estimates by Europeans contacting a tribe for the first time were after the effects of the epidemic. Colonizers found what appeared to be ghost towns–abandoned villages, human remains scattered around, and occasionally a few survivors bearing the marks of having had a terrible disease (George Vancouver exploring Puget Sound writes about this).

posts.body:
Pre-contact Native American History

Many of the myths surrounding Native American history serve a purpose in justifying the deliberate genocide of the land’s indigenous people. It is important to recognize these so you are able to combat them.

First, consider the ‘pristine myth’, that Native Americans were essentially all hunter-gatherers in temporary shelters who did not fundamentally change the environment in which they lived. This is completely false: most tribes were agriculturalists and all tribes deliberately shaped the world in which they lived. Pre-contact Americas were home to beautiful forms of architecture, large cities, and the most advanced urban planning the world had yet seen.

Second, be aware of small population myths. Hand-in-hand with pristine myths, many assume (and textbooks do little to dissuade) that the Americas were sparsely populated with few people scattered across the continents. While it’s uncertain exactly how many people lived here, the Americas had cities larger than European cities. North America has up to 7 million people, and estimates for all of the Americas go up to over 100 million people.

Third, look out for outside-influence conspiracy theories. Some people claim that the incredible accomplishments could not have been done by Native Americans. Alternate 'theories’ include aliens, 7th century BCE immigrants from Jerusalem, and 2nd century BCE Minoans (the latter two groups apparently sailed across the Atlantic).

Fourth, understand the true role of disease decimation in the Americas. Many of the myths surrounding Native American history serve a purpose in justifying the deliberate genocide of the land’s indigenous people. It is important to recognize these so you are able to combat them.

First, consider the ‘pristine myth’, that Native Americans were essentially all hunter-gatherers in temporary shelters who did not fundamentally change the environment in which they lived. This is completely false: most tribes were agriculturalists and all tribes deliberately shaped the world in which they lived. Pre-contact Americas were home to beautiful forms of architecture, large cities, and the most advanced urban planning the world had yet seen.

Second, be aware of small population myths. Hand-in-hand with pristine myths, many assume (and textbooks do little to dissuade) that the Americas were sparsely populated with few people scattered across the continents. While it’s uncertain exactly how many people lived here, the Americas had cities larger than European cities. North America has up to 7 million people, and estimates for all of the Americas go up to over 100 million people.

posts.body:
Pre-contact Native American Linguistics

America is unique for the incredible diversity of its indigenous languages. There are approximately 1,200 indigenous languages spoken across the Americas, including about 296 spoken (or formerly spoken) languages north of Mexico.

Compared to Europe, which has just three language families (Indo-European, Finno-Ugric, Turkic) and one language isolate (Basque), there are 180 language families and isolates north of Mexico. In particular, the California region has 18 language families with 74 languages!

The most popular of these languages today are Diné bizaad (Navajo), in the Na-Dene language family with 170,000 total speakers; Nēhiyawēwin (Cree), in the Algic language family with 96,000 total speakers; and Kalaallisut (Greenlandic), in the Eskimo-Aleut language family with 57,000 total speakers.

posts.body:
Native American Early Migration History

When understanding migration in the Americas, it is important to recognize the impact different ideas have on the view of things like land rights. If, as mainstream viewpoints contend, they recently crossed over from Asia and happened to get here first, and then spent their time fighting with each other over land and resources, it helps justify the Europeans who simply did the same thing later on. However, Native American viewpoints say they have been here since time immemorial, it justifies their continued stewardship over this land. Increasingly, evidence supports the second theory.

It’s also important to discuss the Clovis myth. For many years, history class taught (and still teach, despite this being firmly disproven) that the first sign of inhabitance was the tool culture found in New Mexico that is approximately 13,000 years old. It follows a migration model that people walked across the Bering Straits and then walked down an ice-free corridor through Canada. We know now this to be false, but it is still the prominent theory in most history books for high schoolers.

New models of thinking suggest that the first group of people entered Beringia between 30,000 and 40,000 years ago. From there, they left in groups, some walking before the glacier blocked the route, some in boats going down the shore towards California. We are now certain that South America was populated over a thousand years before Clovis (evidence: the Monte Verde II site in Chile), and that North America was populated at least ten thousand years before Clovis (evidence: White Sands footprints in New Mexico). People were living throughout South America before modern humans made it to England.

To help people put these dates in historical context, here they are listed with contemporaneous events from Afro-Eurasia.

Entrance through Beringia: ~35kya–first evidence of people inhabiting Japan, Neanderthals inhabit much of Europe and are making cave art.
Evidence of people in New Mexico: ~23kya–humans have begun making ceramics (evidence from Czech Republic)
Evidence of people in Chile: ~14kya–Holocene extinction begins. European cave art is likely being made by Homo sapiens rather than Neanderthals.
The first human civilization, Sumer (Mesopotamia) existed ~6kya.

The terms “Old World” and “New World” do nothing to describe the true history of when these regions were populated.

tags: put that thing back where it came from or so help me
posts.summary: [image description: an article headline that says Arts; Britain can't decide whether it should send its looted treasures back to...
posts.body:
[image description: an article headline that says Arts; Britain can’t decide whether it should send its looted treasures back to their rightful owners; Updated 31st October 2021]

This editorial discusses the looting and possible repatriation of historical artifacts from Benin in West Africa.

A few highlights:

“The British government believes that the museum is the right home for the bronzes as it makes them accessible to the largest number of people and, as a leading museum in one of the world’s most global cities, has the best facilities for their upkeep.
This is an argument that many find insulting and steeped in exactly the type of British imperial thinking that saw the artifacts looted in the first place.
‘This logic suggests that Nigeria is a poorer country that in incapable of properly looking after the artifacts that colonialists stole, despite the fact there is a state-of-the-art museum awaiting them in Nigeria. It’s a classic racist argument that Britain is a place of refinement and knows best,’ said Kehinde Andrews, Professor of Black Studies at Birmingham City University.”

On the specific topic of the Benin Bronzes, a government spokesperson told CNN this week that museums operate 'independently of the government with decisions relating to collections care and management, including whether to make loans of any objects, taken by the trustees of each institution,’ pointing out that the bronzes are a private collection rather than a part of the national collection.
For now, the British Museum is prohibited from giving its artifacts back by British law, although it is reportedly discussing possible loans to the planned Edo Museum of West African Art in Nigeria.

Tl;dr: Everyone agrees these artifacts should be given back, but are unwilling to actually do it.

posts.summary: Intro to Pre-contact Native American History
posts.body:
Intro to Pre-contact Native American History

November is National Native American Heritage Month. In recognition of this, and in the understanding of the terrible level of Native American education in most schools, this blog will spend this month discussing the history of pre-European contact societies in the lands that are now the United States and Canada. This post will be a very broad, simplistic overview to provide context for more in-depth posts for the rest of the month.

The indigenous Americans lived across both continents and on every nearby island mass, including Greenland. The people north the Rio Grande were incredibly diverse in language, culture, values, religious practice, and just about everything. Trying to describe all of them is a bit like trying to describe all Europeans. Still, there are some points that can be made.

Americans were, by and large, more respectful of the environment than we are today. However, it would be wrong to say that they lived among nature without substantially impacting it. This idea, termed the pristine myth by professor and geographer William Denevan, is absolutely false.

Among the many different biomes inhabited by many different peoples, there is not one that was left untouched and untended by human hands. From controlled wildfires common in the West to prey drives in the East to the long history of genetic modification and agriculture everywhere, Americans interacted with and controlled their environments just as all people do.

Indigenous architecture was varied and unique, corresponding with the needs of the climate and the social requirements of each society. Most groups had permanent housing structures. While a minority of tribes were nomadic, even they interfaced with settled groups regularly and often had semi-permanent housing (for example, a permanent winter location). While tipis did exist, especially in tribes in and around the Great Plains, it is a false stereotype that they were used and the default continentwide. Likewise in the North, igloos were used by some groups (and could be semi-permanent or permanent housing), but peoples across Alaska, Canada, and Greenland had numerous forms of architecture of varying materials, such as the Aleutian barabara.

The names of Native American groups are often not their legal name. It was common practice for colonizers to ask a group what they called their neighbors and adopt this term. As an example, the Nʉmʉnʉʉ nation is also called the Comanche, a Southern Ute word that means “enemy”. This is a common occurrence.

This blog will use the name that groups call themselves but will make reference to their legal names to avoid confusion. It will also use any official name without edits. For example, the Aniyvwiya people of the United Cherokee Nation of Indians.

posts.body:
Mary Shelley

The woman herself, today we celebrate Halloween by taking a look at Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley (1797-1851).

Born in Somers Town, London to a feminist mother (Mary Wollstonecraft, A Vindication of the Rights of Woman, 1792) and an anarchist father (William Godwin, An Enquiry Concerning Political Justice, 1793), Shelley’s mother died almost immediately, leaving Godwin to raise both her and her older half-sister (her mother’s illegitimate child) despite being deeply in debt. Shelley’s childhood was largely happy, but when Godwin remarried, she disliked her new stepmother and stepsiblings.

In 1812, she was sent to live with the Baxter family near Dundee, Scotland, a family of radicals (the 18th century political movement that would advocate for democratic reform and eventually turn into social liberalism). It was here she started writing.

In 1814, she met Percy Bysshe Shelley, himself a radical reformer who had alienated his wealthy aristocratic family due to his plans to redistribute their hereditary wealth. They eloped and left for France.

Their marriage was not perfect–though both believed marriage to be regressive and in free love, Percy had extramarital partners while Mary did not. Mary’s father refused to have anything to do with her after the elopement, and neither had as much money as they were used to.

In 1831, Mary Shelley, Percy Shelley, Lord Byron, and John William Polidori sat in a room, where Lord Byron dared them each to write a ghost story. What started as a short story became Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus (1818), notable for Mary Shelley being perhaps the only person to invent a monster rather than take one from mythology.

I end today’s tale at the start of Frankenstein, but there’s more to say about her eventual marriage to Percy Shelley, her charity lesbians, single mothers, and adultresses, the numerous attempts at blackmail, and her feminist principles. You could–and people have–written many books about her life. One of the most notable figures in literary history, Shelley’s other works, including Valperga (1823) and The Last Man (1826) are becoming more and more widely read.

posts.body:
Emma Orczy

Baroness Emma Magdolna Rozália Mária Jozefa Borbála Orczy de Orci (1865-1947) was a Hungarian-born British writer known for inventing the ‘hero with a secret identity’ trope.

Born in Tarnaörs, Hungary and raised across Europe during a period of unpopularity for nobility, Orczy started writing for money. Her first stories were unsuccessful, but in 1903 she wrote The Scarlet Pimpernel. A massive success, especially as a play on London’s West End, it introduced a number of tropes now standard in superhero media.

It used a hero with a secret identity with a signature weapon, the ability to outthink opponents, a calling card (the eponymous scarlet pimpernel, a small flower), and an in-universe following. Her protagonist, Sir Percy Blakeney, hides behind a public face as a somewhat stupid playboy–similar to Bruce Wayne.

Orczy wrote over a dozen sequels, as well as rather popular mystery novels. Lady Molly of Scotland Yard is an early example of a female detective. All told, Orcazy wrote over 50 novels and a number of short stories and plays.

tags: what's love got to do with it
posts.body:
Tina Turner

The Queen of Rock ‘n’ Roll, Tina Turner (born Anna Mae Bullock, 1939) is generally considered one of the greatest music artists of the 20th century.

Born in rural Tennessee, Turner sang in the church choir and worked as a domestic worker. She was a tomboy and an athlete in high school, and after graduation worked as a nurse’s aide in St. Louis.

In the late 1950s, Turner began singing in St. Louis nightclubs, where she met Ike Turner. She began working in music and wrote and recorded “A Fool In Love”, which became a hit single.

Ike and Tina toured together for years and found massive popularity across the country. The name “Tina Turner” was, at the time, trademarked by Ike Turner (at this point her husband), making it difficult for her to leave. In 1978, Tina filed for divorce and began her solo career, still as Tina Turner.

Though it took some years for Turner to find her feet on her own, in 1983 her career resurged and she was propelled to superstardom. She played a number of successful world tours and starred in Mad Max (1985) opposite Mel Gibson.

As a musician, Tina Turner was showstopping and brilliant. Her songs, inarguably “Black music”, were popular in every demographic. She has received 12 Grammys, sold over 100 million records, and has been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Twice.

Here are four songs to get you started on Tina Turner’s music

  1. Goldeneye (1995)
  2. What’s Love Got To Do With It? (1984)
  3. Let’s Stay Together (1983, Al Green cover)
  4. Proud Mary (1971)

trail.content_raw:
Tina Turner

The Queen of Rock ‘n’ Roll, Tina Turner (born Anna Mae Bullock, 1939) is generally considered one of the greatest music artists of the 20th century.

Born in rural Tennessee, Turner sang in the church choir and worked as a domestic worker. She was a tomboy and an athlete in high school, and after graduation worked as a nurse’s aide in St. Louis.

In the late 1950s, Turner began singing in St. Louis nightclubs, where she met Ike Turner. She began working in music and wrote and recorded “A Fool In Love”, which became a hit single.

Ike and Tina toured together for years and found massive popularity across the country. The name “Tina Turner” was, at the time, trademarked by Ike Turner (at this point her husband), making it difficult for her to leave. In 1978, Tina filed for divorce and began her solo career, still as Tina Turner.

Though it took some years for Turner to find her feet on her own, in 1983 her career resurged and she was propelled to superstardom. She played a number of successful world tours and starred in Mad Max (1985) opposite Mel Gibson.

As a musician, Tina Turner was showstopping and brilliant. Her songs, inarguably “Black music”, were popular in every demographic. She has received 12 Grammys, sold over 100 million records, and has been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Twice.

Here are four songs to get you started on Tina Turner’s music

  1. Goldeneye (1995)
  2. What’s Love Got To Do With It? (1984)
  3. Let’s Stay Together (1983, Al Green cover)
  4. Proud Mary (1971)

posts.body:
Alice Ball

One of history’s finest chemists, Alice Ball (1892-1916) was a Black woman who developed an incredibly effective treatment for leprosy now known as the “Ball Method.”

Born to a middle-class family in Seattle, Washington, Ball studied chemistry and pharmacy at the University of Washington before attending the College of Hawaii to study for a master’s degree in chemistry, where she studied the use of native plants in medicine.

Due to her expertise, Ball was asked to research the use of chaulmoogra oil on leprosy. The Hawaiian island of Molokai was, at the time, a ‘leper colony’ where patients were essentially sent to die. Chaulmoogra oil was the best medicine at the time, but all methods of application had severe problems. At age 23, Ball developed a technique to make the oil injectable.

It was a brilliant solution, but Ball died before she could publish her findings (officially due to tuberculosis, likely due to the hazards associated with chemical lab work) and her work was stolen by Arthur L. Dean, who published it without any credit and named it after himself. It was not until the 1970s the Alice Ball was given the place in history she deserved from the beginning.

posts.body:
Laura Redden Searing

A deaf poet and journalist, Laura Searing (1839-1923) was a famous writer and ardent pro-Unionist during the American Civil War.

Born in Maryland, Searing lost her hearing at age 11 due to spinal meningitis. She enrolled in the Missouri School for the Deaf, but was unable to continue her education due to the intersection of her identities–the National Deaf-Mute College (now Gallaudet University) did not accept women, and colleges that did accept women were unwilling to accommodate a deaf person.

As a writer, Searing started submitting poems to Harper’s Magazine in 1857. Her topics included deafness and sign language. In 1859, the St. Louis Presbyterian hired her as a columnist and assistant editor before she became an editorialist for the St. Louis Republican. It was around this time she started using the pseudonym Howard Glyndon, though in her published works she also included her real name.

Searing was sent to Washington, D.C. in 1861 to cover the American Civil War. She was a pro-Union loyalist who also wrote poems about her time there. After, she traveled to Europe as a correspondent for The New York Times. She continued to write until her death.

I’m sick of hearing so much about love!
I can’t take up a magazine or journal
But ’t is the same old story,—Love! Love! Love!
Whether in poem, prose, essay, or tale;
And all my music’s set to silly words.

Sweet Bells Jangled (1874)

posts.body:
Yekaterina Mikhailova-Demina

Ekaterina Illarionovna Mikhailova-Demina, in Russian Екатерина Илларионовна Михайлова-Дёмина (1925-2019) was a Russian military doctor and recon officer.

She was born in Leningrad and grew up in an orphanage, volunteering for military service and working in a military hospital at age 15. When her hospital was evacuated as the Germans advanced through Russia, she stayed behind to work as a field medic for the Red Army.

Mikhailova-Demina volunteered for front-line service in the 369th Independent Naval Infantry Battalion. She treated and evacuated wounded and scouted enemy territory. She participated in a commando-style operation to assault a Nazi bunker and retake the city of Bilhorod-Dnistrovskyi. In her military career, Mikhailova-Demina was seriously wounded three times and personally saved the lives of hundreds of men.

She was awarded the Florence Nightingale Medal for her work during WWII and, in 1950, became a doctor. She was nominated three times for the Hero of the Soviet Union, the highest distinction in the country, but was turned down due to sexism. Mikhailova-Demina received it belatedly in 1990.

posts.body:
Minggatu

A famous Mongolian astronomer and mathematician, Minggatu (1692-1763) was a scientist at the Qing Court.

Born what is now Inner Mongolia of the Sharaid clan, he was an excellent student. He worked at the Imperial Observatory on drafting the calendar and studying the armillary sphere (a model of objects in the sky).

Of note, he was the first person in China to calculate infinite series and he obtained more than 10 formulae. He also first established what would later be called Catalan numbers, a sequence of natural numbers helpful in dealing with recursively define objects. Though these numbers would be named after a European, it was Minggatu who discovered them. His work is incredibly remarkable in that he worked with series, trigonometry, and logarithms with algebra and without differential and integral calculus.

Also of note was his work in surveying the Dhungar Khanate, which allowed the first atlas of China drawn with scientific methods, the Complete Atlas of the Empire, to be finished.

For three years, he was the administrator of the Imperial Astronomical Bureau. His courtesy name was Jing An. He was an innovator in math, science, and analytical researcher. In 2002, a minor planet was named after him.

posts.body:
Jonas Salk

October 24th is World Polio Day.

Jonas Edward Salk (1914-1995) was an American virologist who developed one of the first successful polio vaccines and refused to make it profitable to maximize global distribution.

Salk was born in New York City to Ashkenazi Jewish parents and quickly excelled in education. He enrolled at the City College of New York at the age of 15 and then the New York University Medical School. Here, though he was brilliant, he found he was far more interested in lab research than practicing as a doctor and began to focus on infectious diseases.

He worked at a number of prestigious hospitals and well-regarded labs throughout the country, helping develop an influenza vaccine only a few years after the influenza virus had been discovered.

In 1947, Salk got his own laboratory at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine but found it insufficient for his needs. WOrking with the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis and the Mellon family, he built his own research lab to study polio. He worked on a ‘killed-virus’ vaccine.

In 1952, Salk began testing the vaccine on human children. By 1954, more than a million people received the vaccine, and in 1955 it was announced as safe.

The vaccine was immensely successful around the world. Salk refused to patent it, though it was calculated to have a worth of about $7 billion dollars. He began a public figure and a celebrity, much to his own annoyance.

His academic philosophy was one of love towards humankind–Salk wanted to help as many people as he could. He rejected the divide between the sciences, humanities, and arts was harmful to the mental complexity that someone might achieve. He wanted to educate a generation of 'biophilosophers’, that is

“Someone who draws upon the scriptures of nature, recognizing that we are the product of the process of evolution, and understands that we have become the process itself, through the emergence and evolution of our consciousness, our awareness, our capacity to imagine and anticipate the future, and to choose from among alternatives.”

Jonas Edward Salk (1914-1995) was an American virologist who developed one of the first successful polio vaccines and refused to make it profitable to maximize global distribution.

Salk was born in New York City to Ashkenazi Jewish parents and quickly excelled in education. He enrolled at the City College of New York at the age of 15 and then the New York University Medical School. Here, though he was brilliant, he found he was far more interested in lab research than practicing as a doctor and began to focus on infectious diseases.

He worked at a number of prestigious hospitals and well-regarded labs throughout the country, helping develop an influenza vaccine only a few years after the influenza virus had been discovered.

In 1947, Salk got his own laboratory at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine but found it insufficient for his needs. WOrking with the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis and the Mellon family, he built his own research lab to study polio. He worked on a ‘killed-virus’ vaccine.

In 1952, Salk began testing the vaccine on human children. By 1954, more than a million people received the vaccine, and in 1955 it was announced as safe.

The vaccine was immensely successful around the world. Salk refused to patent it, though it was calculated to have a worth of about $7 billion dollars. He began a public figure and a celebrity, much to his own annoyance.

His academic philosophy was one of love towards humankind–Salk wanted to help as many people as he could. He rejected the divide between the sciences, humanities, and arts was harmful to the mental complexity that someone might achieve. He wanted to educate a generation of 'biophilosophers’, that is

“Someone who draws upon the scriptures of nature, recognizing that we are the product of the process of evolution, and understands that we have become the process itself, through the emergence and evolution of our consciousness, our awareness, our capacity to imagine and anticipate the future, and to choose from among alternatives.”
